values.title: srcsim-ci-default jenkins job is broken

content.raw:
http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/srcsim-ci-default-trusty-amd64/30/console

The srcsim deb repo is added in the [DOCKER_POSTINSTALL_HOOK](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/14e9fb5946949c8dee2722c56f8a88c87078cb71/jenkins-scripts/docker/srcsim-compilation.bash?fileviewer=file-view-default#srcsim-compilation.bash-39), but it needs to be added sooner than that. Should we create a `DOCKER_PREINSTALL_HOOK` earlier in the file instead?

http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/srcsim-ci-default-trusty-amd64/30/console

The srcsim deb repo is added in the DOCKER_POSTINSTALL_HOOK, but it needs to be added sooner than that. Should we create a DOCKER_PREINSTALL_HOOK earlier in the file instead?

content.html:

values.title: Set bitbucket build status for default and release branch builds

content.raw:
We currently set the bitbucket build status for the `ci-pr_any` builds, but it would be nice to have it for the default and release branch builds, so we can browse recent jenkins builds from the commit view in bitbucket.

For example, `ign-math` has lots of build status because it has pipelines and appveyor testing enabled:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/branch/ign-math3

but `ign-msgs` only has jenkins builds enabled:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/commits/branch/default

values.title: Use brew bottle more and host bottles at bintray

content.raw:
There are some useful recommendations in [this homebrew comment](https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/issues/2572#issuecomment-298874118):

* tap maintainers should be able to push to a pull request branch, so we should be able to build bottles even if the `osrfbuild` fork wasn't used

* use `brew bottle --write` and `brew bottle --merge` instead of our [current sed command](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/389b041e0bb18b3361c17d6707d2d3537eb6efec/jenkins-scripts/lib/homebrew_bottle_pullrequest.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#homebrew_bottle_pullrequest.bash-83)
content.html:
There are some useful recommendations in this homebrew comment:

  • tap maintainers should be able to push to a pull request branch, so we should be able to build bottles even if the osrfbuild fork wasn't used

  • use brew bottle --write and brew bottle --merge instead of our current sed command

values.title: Gazebo windows CI qt5 dep needs to be pre-installed

content.raw: We are hosting a [zip file of qt5](http://packages.osrfoundation.org/win32/deps/qt5-x64-static-release.zip qt5-x64-static-release.zip) for use in gazebo CI on windows, and it was added to the install scripts in pull request #415 (in gazebo-base-windows.bat at [line 28](#!/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/415/fix-gazebo-windows-build/diff#Ljenkins-scripts/lib/gazebo-base-windows.batT28)), but it is a static build and caused linking errors. So the use of that qt5 build was [reverted in favor of a pre-installed version](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/b79c94879deb505918d2f1e71b011a1171ce1e56?at=gazebo8) in order to fix the build. We should fix the downloadable dependency at some point.
content.html: We are hosting a zip file of qt5 for use in gazebo CI on windows, and it was added to the install scripts in pull request #415 (in gazebo-base-windows.bat at line 28), but it is a static build and caused linking errors. So the use of that qt5 build was reverted in favor of a pre-installed version in order to fix the build. We should fix the downloadable dependency at some point.

values.title: Separate packages.osrfoundation.org from build.osrfoundation.org

content.raw:
The jenkins master at build.osrfoundation.org is frequently going offline due to a lack of disk space. The bulk of the space is occupied by packages and files hosted at packages.osrfoundation.org.

Should we just separate these into two separate machines? It's really annoying for the buildfarm to keep going offline.
content.html:
The jenkins master at build.osrfoundation.org is frequently going offline due to a lack of disk space. The bulk of the space is occupied by packages and files hosted at packages.osrfoundation.org.

Should we just separate these into two separate machines? It's really annoying for the buildfarm to keep going offline.

values.title: SDFORMAT_MAJOR_VERSION not set in gazebo multi-any jobs

content.raw:
The [gazebo-ci-pr_any+sdformat_any+ign_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any+sdformat_any+ign_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) job builds gazebo with sdformat and some ignition packages from source. @iche033 recently tried building a branch of `gazebo7` it with a custom branch of  `sdf4` and `ign-math2`, but it failed while trying to install dependencies.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any+sdformat_any+ign_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/5/

I believe it failed because the `SDFORMAT_MAJOR_VERSION` variable wasn't set when [boilerplate_prepare.sh is called in gazebo-base-default.bash](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/b4b8050b6542fbedc2d1beb0b6e4125b0f299a1b/jenkins-scripts/docker/lib/gazebo-base-default.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#gazebo-base-default.bash-22), so it defaulted to major version 5. I made a test branch with a different default value for @iche033 to get his test running, but it would be nice if we could handle this better. Maybe we need an extra if block where we check if sdformat is being built and call an sdformat_version_hook if so.
content.html:
The gazebo-ci-pr_any+sdformat_any+ign_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia job builds gazebo with sdformat and some ignition packages from source. @iche033 recently tried building a branch of gazebo7 it with a custom branch of sdf4 and ign-math2, but it failed while trying to install dependencies.

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any+sdformat_any+ign_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/5/

I believe it failed because the SDFORMAT_MAJOR_VERSION variable wasn't set when boilerplate_prepare.sh is called in gazebo-base-default.bash, so it defaulted to major version 5. I made a test branch with a different default value for @iche033 to get his test running, but it would be nice if we could handle this better. Maybe we need an extra if block where we check if sdformat is being built and call an sdformat_version_hook if so.

values.title: Migrate homebrew CI to newer distro

content.raw: We are currently using macOS 10.10 yosemite for all our CI jobs (except building bottles). It looks like high sierra will be [released on Sept 25](https://www.apple.com/macos/high-sierra/), at which point homebrew will no longer support yosemite. So we should migrate to El Capitan and then upgrade the software on the yosemite machine to High Sierra.

values.title: Major version appended to project name in inconsistent pattern

content.raw:
We have been appending the major version number of a package to its project name for the ignition packages for a little while now. It's not always part of the debian metadata though.

New packages with major version 0 often don't have the 0 in the debian metadata (for example [ignition-cmake](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake-release/src/b7e55f502966b99d5f033b3685d34517eb00afd0/xenial/debian/changelog?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default)), but once they reach version 2, it is added (for example [ignition-transport2](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport2-release/src/8d4c1413e2bcbbd41c390dd73d9a729458651233/xenial/debian/changelog?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) and [ignition-math4](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math4-release/src/c01af0b1d89c1751bf004ae403971502f2c4ec2c/xenial/debian/changelog?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default).

The reason I bring this up now is that I just tried to make a prerelease of ignition-math4 and noticed that its tarball doesn't have the extra major version (ie `ignition-math-4.0.0~pre2.tar.bz2`). This causes the `release.py` script to fail since it expects a tarball named `ignition-math4-4.0.0~pre2.tar.bz2`.
content.html:
We have been appending the major version number of a package to its project name for the ignition packages for a little while now. It's not always part of the debian metadata though.

New packages with major version 0 often don't have the 0 in the debian metadata (for example ignition-cmake), but once they reach version 2, it is added (for example ignition-transport2 and ignition-math4.

The reason I bring this up now is that I just tried to make a prerelease of ignition-math4 and noticed that its tarball doesn't have the extra major version (ie ignition-math-4.0.0~pre2.tar.bz2). This causes the release.py script to fail since it expects a tarball named ignition-math4-4.0.0~pre2.tar.bz2.

* _Z12Base64EncodePKcjRNSt7__cxx1112basic_stringIcEE
* Base64Encode(char const*, unsigned int, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char>&)

...

values.title: Force docker cache invalidation

content.raw:
We made a new release of sdformat4 in order to access a new feature that hadn't been released yet in sdformat5. Due to a quirk of the debian metadata, the `libsdformat4-dev` installs the `sdformat-sdf` version 5.2 package, which didn't have that new feature. So I released `sdformat-sdf` version 5.3 with the feature, but the docker cache didn't notice the new package so the test continues to fail:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/349/testReport/junit/(root)/PhysicsEngines_AttachLightTest/LinkLight_0/

I'm going to try a custom branch of release-tools to invalidate the cache.
content.html:
We made a new release of sdformat4 in order to access a new feature that hadn't been released yet in sdformat5. Due to a quirk of the debian metadata, the libsdformat4-dev installs the sdformat-sdf version 5.2 package, which didn't have that new feature. So I released sdformat-sdf version 5.3 with the feature, but the docker cache didn't notice the new package so the test continues to fail:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/349/testReport/junit/(root)/PhysicsEngines_AttachLightTest/LinkLight_0/

I'm going to try a custom branch of release-tools to invalidate the cache.

values.title: ign-msgs1 pre-release issues

content.raw:
@caguero and I were trying to install the ign-msgs1 pre-release on [ign-transport's pipelines](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/branches/compare/pipelines_4%0Dign-transport4#diff) and we ran into a few issues.

We reproduced the setup locally with:

~~~
docker run -ti ubuntu:16.04 /bin/bash
apt update
apt install -y mercurial
hg clone https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport -b pipelines_4
cd ign-transport
# follow pipelines instructions from here
~~~

> Note that we're installing `libignition-msgs-dev` instead of `libignition-msgs1-dev` because that's the package on the pre-release repo, is it supposed to be like that?

The problem happens when ign-transport fails to `find_package(ignition-msgs1)`. It does find it when ign-msgs1 is build from source, which indicates the problem is on the debs.

> Note that  `find_package(ignition-msgs0)` fails and `find_package(ignition-msgs)` succeeds

Some possibly useful output:

~~~
# dpkg -L libignition-msgs-dev | grep cmake
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-msgs
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-msgs/ignition-msgs-config.cmake

~~~

/usr/share/doc/libignition-msgs/copyright

~~~

total 16
drwxr-xr-x  4 root root 4096 Nov 17 00:08 ./
drwxr-xr-x 35 root root 4096 Nov 17 00:08 ../
drwxr-xr-x  3 root root 4096 Nov 17 00:08 math3/
drwxr-xr-x  3 root root 4096 Nov 17 00:08 msgs1/
~~~
content.html:
@caguero and I were trying to install the ign-msgs1 pre-release on ign-transport's pipelines and we ran into a few issues.

We reproduced the setup locally with:

docker run -ti ubuntu:16.04 /bin/bash
apt update
apt install -y mercurial
hg clone https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport -b pipelines_4
cd ign-transport
# follow pipelines instructions from here

Note that we're installing libignition-msgs-dev instead of libignition-msgs1-dev because that's the package on the pre-release repo, is it supposed to be like that?

The problem happens when ign-transport fails to find_package(ignition-msgs1). It does find it when ign-msgs1 is build from source, which indicates the problem is on the debs.

Note that find_package(ignition-msgs0) fails and find_package(ignition-msgs) succeeds

Some possibly useful output:

values.title: Dedicate separate macOS CI machines for gazebo and sdformat/ignition?

content.raw:
We currently have 3 macOS CI machines so that we can build bottles for the 3 OS distros supported by Homebrew, but we only use one machine for our regular CI testing in order to have consistent results. Since the gazebo builds can take a long time, it could be convenient to use one machine for building gazebo and a separate machine for sdformat and ignition CI. I believe this could be configured with the following patch:

~~~
diff -r aea27fa1cd4f jenkins-scripts/dsl/gazebo.dsl
--- a/jenkins-scripts/dsl/gazebo.dsl	Tue Jan 23 12:57:44 2018 +0100
+++ b/jenkins-scripts/dsl/gazebo.dsl	Tue Jan 23 18:01:44 2018 -0800
@@ -518,6 +518,8 @@
                               "https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo")
 gazebo_brew_ci_any_job.with
 {
+    label "osx_gazebo"
+
     steps {
       shell("""\
             #!/bin/bash -xe
@@ -557,6 +559,8 @@
 
   gazebo_brew_ci_job.with
   {
+      label "osx_gazebo"
+
       triggers {
         scm('@daily')
       }
~~~

Does anyone object to this proposal?

values.title: Set a BUILD_TOOL variable to switch between catkin_tools and catkin_make_isolated

content.raw:
The most supported build tool for ROS projects is currently `catkin_make_isolated` which is what the servicesim team is using locally.

The release script `jenkins-scripts/docker/lib/_ros_setup_buildsh.bash` uses catkin_tools. In order to implement CI for servicesim in #!/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/525/ I copied the file and adapted it to use catkin_make_isolated but since there's a lot still common to both scripts that now needs to be maintained in two places we discussed using a `BUILD_TOOL` variable to switch which tool is used and reuinify the scripts.

I will have a very simple straw-man PR that simply passes the BUILD_TOOL variable down to the generated build.sh script today or Monday.

content.raw:
I noticed that some gazebo_ros CI builds were failing even though they passed on my local machine. I tracked this down to my use of ros-shadow-fixed locally, so I submitted pull request #570. That pull request hasn't been merged, but there has been a sync of packages to the public repo, so it should be working now.

The builds on optimus are working:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64&build=100)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64/100/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64/100/

but the builds on r2d2 are failing to find the correct opencv package:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64&build=101)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64/101/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ros_gazebo8_pkgs-ci-pr_any_kinetic-xenial-amd64/101/

  as an include dir, which is not found.
~~~

Maybe there's a problem with squid or the docker cache on r2d2?

values.title: Compiler support for gazebo11

content.raw:
We are planning to use c++17 features in the experimental gazebo11 version, and this is pushing the limits of what is available. On bionic, gcc8 is ok, and Visual Studio 2017 (15.7) is ok, but the libc++ that ships with xcode9 on macOS high sierra doesn't have many c++17 features.

There is a [cryptic comment on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/50835358) claiming that xcode10 will contain the filesystem feature, so I installed the xcode 10 beta 2 on a test machine, but I didn't see any c++17 headers.

I'm currently testing a build of llvm from source (`brew install llvm --with-toolchain`), since c++17 support is present upstream. I'll see how difficult this is to support.

Related comment threads:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/438/removal-of-boost/diff#comment-67720520
* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/312/update-to-protobuf3-and-fix-compiler/diff#comment-67739406
content.html:
We are planning to use c++17 features in the experimental gazebo11 version, and this is pushing the limits of what is available. On bionic, gcc8 is ok, and Visual Studio 2017 (15.7) is ok, but the libc++ that ships with xcode9 on macOS high sierra doesn't have many c++17 features.

There is a cryptic comment on stackoverflow claiming that xcode10 will contain the filesystem feature, so I installed the xcode 10 beta 2 on a test machine, but I didn't see any c++17 headers.

I'm currently testing a build of llvm from source (brew install llvm --with-toolchain), since c++17 support is present upstream. I'll see how difficult this is to support.

Related comment threads:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/438/removal-of-boost/diff#comment-67720520

values.title: Store vcpkg dependencies (DEPEN_PKGS) in source repo instead of release-tools

content.raw:
For the windows jobs using colcon, we currently store the list of dependencies to install with vcpkg inside the release-tools build script for that package. I think that is brittle; it would be nicer to store it in a metadata file in the source repository.

values.title: CI can't `hg pull` for pull requests from private forks

content.raw:
Here is an example of a pull request from a private fork to a public repo:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/pull-requests/100/merge-private-into-public/diff

The jenkins build failed since it was unable to `hg pull` from the private repo:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=subt-ci-pr_any-bionic-amd64&build=23)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-ci-pr_any-bionic-amd64/23/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-ci-pr_any-bionic-amd64/23/

One option would be to use the bitbucket API to get the diff proposed by the pull request and apply that to the target branch:

* https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/osrf/subt/pullrequests/100/diff

For this specific pull request, I'm not worried about the CI, but I thought it would be good to be aware of this issue in case we get more pull requests from private forks.
content.html:
Here is an example of a pull request from a private fork to a public repo:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/pull-requests/100/merge-private-into-public/diff

The jenkins build failed since it was unable to hg pull from the private repo:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-ci-pr_any-bionic-amd64/23/

One option would be to use the bitbucket API to get the diff proposed by the pull request and apply that to the target branch:

  • https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/osrf/subt/pullrequests/100/diff

For this specific pull request, I'm not worried about the CI, but I thought it would be good to be aware of this issue in case we get more pull requests from private forks.

values.title: Use `make codecheck` on ubuntu

content.raw:
Libraries using `ign-cmake` can use `make codecheck` to run cppcheck, but older libraries still rely on `tools/code_check.sh`. For that reason, Jenkins still uses `code_check.sh`, so even the new libraries need to have that script.

It would be good to use `make codecheck` for the libraries that support it, so that we can remove the custom script from them. This is becoming more pressing as the cppcheck results start to diverge.
content.html:
Libraries using ign-cmake can use make codecheck to run cppcheck, but older libraries still rely on tools/code_check.sh. For that reason, Jenkins still uses code_check.sh, so even the new libraries need to have that script.

It would be good to use make codecheck for the libraries that support it, so that we can remove the custom script from them. This is becoming more pressing as the cppcheck results start to diverge.

values.title: End of life for gazebo8 dependencies?

content.raw: Gazebo8 uses `ign-math3`, `ign-msgs0`, and `ign-transport3`. Since gazebo8 has reached end of life, are those packages EOL also? The main thing we would do is remove them from our CI matrix in [ignition.dsl](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/c3ff97c72117e91ae5c5c1594f62096251ec5718/jenkins-scripts/dsl/ignition.dsl?fileviewer=file-view-default#ignition.dsl-26).
content.html: Gazebo8 uses ign-math3, ign-msgs0, and ign-transport3. Since gazebo8 has reached end of life, are those packages EOL also? The main thing we would do is remove them from our CI matrix in ignition.dsl.

values.title: Update gzserver check for Ignition

While it doesn't have any negative effects, it is weird to see that check when testing Ignition libraries.

values.title: release.py doesn't catch `hg tag`, `hg push` errors

content.raw:
I recently tried to make a release to a protected branch, and `hg push` failed, but the `release.py` script didn't detect the failure; it just kept going. I believe it's due to this logic:

* #!/osrf/release-tools/src/03d41f12caa248d6747c656e1324474b3d75c008/release.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#release.py-401:409

Is there a better way to detect git, so we don't ignore valid mercurial failures?

cc @\_jrivero_ @chapulina @nkoenig
content.html:
I recently tried to make a release to a protected branch, and hg push failed, but the release.py script didn't detect the failure; it just kept going. I believe it's due to this logic:

values.title: Need to set USE_GCC8 variable in ignition-abichecker.bash

content.raw:
We are currently setting the `USE_GCC8` variable in the docker scripts for each ignition package:

* #!/osrf/release-tools/src/0094c09b5f43076fb246d9c08643bffd960f8ae7/jenkins-scripts/docker/ign_transport-compilation.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ign_transport-compilation.bash-33
* #!/osrf/release-tools/src/0094c09b5f43076fb246d9c08643bffd960f8ae7/jenkins-scripts/docker/ign_physics-compilation.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ign_physics-compilation.bash-21

This variable is never set in the [ignition-abichecker.bash](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/0094c09b5f43076fb246d9c08643bffd960f8ae7/jenkins-scripts/docker/ignition-abichecker.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) script, though, so it is failing for various packages:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=33)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/33/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_physics-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/33/

We could try looking in the pipeline script to see if it is installing gcc8?

cc @\_jrivero_

values.title: Consider "Execute concurrent builds if necessary" for ci-pr_any builds

content.raw:
I have noticed that the glados build machine will sometimes sit idle even when there is another ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64 job in the queue, if that same type of job is already running on sentinel. I think we would need to enable the "Execute concurrent builds if necessary" option to fix this.

cc @\_jrivero_

values.title: catkin tools is not python3 compatible

content.raw:
Digging into this followup [#!/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/948/use-python3-instead-of-python-except/diff#comment-138708097](#!/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/948/use-python3-instead-of-python-except/diff#comment-138708097) 

We have switched to use python3 by default. However python3-catkin-tools is uninstallable due to the unavailability of python3-trollius

The scripts support three build mechanisms. catkin\_make, catkin tools, and colcon. Because catkin tools can’t be run on our python3 platforms I’d suggest that we drop support for it and we can rely on either catkin\_make or colcon to provide coverage. 

And to that end I’d suggest that we use colcon as the default as it will be more forward looking for other integrations.
content.html:
Digging into this followup #!/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/948/use-python3-instead-of-python-except/diff#comment-138708097

We have switched to use python3 by default. However python3-catkin-tools is uninstallable due to the unavailability of python3-trollius

The scripts support three build mechanisms. catkin_make, catkin tools, and colcon. Because catkin tools can’t be run on our python3 platforms I’d suggest that we drop support for it and we can rely on either catkin_make or colcon to provide coverage.

And to that end I’d suggest that we use colcon as the default as it will be more forward looking for other integrations.
